questions.question_text: A FortiGate device has multiple VDOMs. Which statement about an administrator account configured with the default prof_admin profile is true?

choices.D: It can upgrade the firmware on the FortiGate device.
choices.A: It can create administrator accounts with access to the same VDOM.
choices.B: It cannot have access to more than one VDOM.
choices.C: It can reset the password for the admin account.

comments.content: It says "administrator account configured with the DEFAULT prof_admin profile" so no permissions were changed.
yes, but the document also says that its permissions can be changed. so in case, if prof_admin is not set to write, you will not be able to configure new admins. Hence the answer is B

discussion.content: The correct answer is A. FortiGate_Security_6.2_Study_Guide-Online (page 26).

A is correct.
The very first line reads ..."Per-VDOM administrator accounts only allow administrative access to specific VDOMs". Secondly, ..."You must use either the prof_admin or a custom profile for per-VDOM administrators."

the answer is B
please check link from fortinet https://docs.fortinet.com/document/fortigate/6.0.0/cookbook/938921/creating-per-vdom-administrators

comments.content: In that link you can see that you can associate the admin with more than one VDOM, at the image.
A is correct, it says "It can create administrator accounts with access to the same VDOM." it doesnt say it can create other prof_admin

discussion.content: Correct answer is B. A is wrong, because an prof_admin account from a VDOM cannot create an prof_admin admin account. This when We are working with multiples VDOMS... not only root.

A = correct. 
B is wrong because it can have access to more than one VDOM
C and D are wrong because it can not change the admin and super_admin account password or do anything at that level or upgrade firmware — all these require Global Access to do so, prof is just local to a VDOM

Technically no answer makes sense. B and C are simply incorrect so chosen answer here is wrong (again). A is true but prof_admin can do a lot more than that. D is also true, although prof_admin can also upgrade through CLI. A is probably the answer they were going for.

comments.content: C is not correct: Even if you assign the prof_admin access profile to other administrators, they will not have all of the same permissions as the admin account. The admin account has some special permissions, such as the ability to reset administrator passwords, that are inherent in that account only.

questions.question_text: Which of the following features is supported by web filter in flow-based inspection mode with NGFW mode set to profile-based?

comments.content: Well done, you have an eye for detail. BUT...answer option B could be correct if the exam says "Static URL Filter". vwboy says there are 2 answers required...

discussion.content:
D is correct, B don't cause missing the word "Filter" (a big jerky trapp)
https://docs.fortinet.com/document/fortigate/6.2.3/cookbook/469806/inspection-mode-differences-for-web-filter
Which of the following features is supported by web filter in flow-based inspection mode with NGFW mode set to profile-based? two answers for this one B and D just came out of exam
B y D son verdaderas, Fortigate_Security_6.2 pagina 374
As jbernard said, D is correct, "static URL" without the FILTER word as not sense.

I don't get why only one?.. I create a security profile - webfilter and I see Fortiguard Category Based (Usage Quotas), Static URL Filtering, Search engines (safe search) and Rating options... A, B, C and D are correct???
B & D are correct as per the FortiOS 6.0 handbook

I set up the scenario when I enable port forwarding in the vip leaves with the ip associated with the wan interface (10.200.1.1), if I disable port forwarding the outgoing ip is the one associated with the VIP (10.200.1.10) Correct answer C

C is correct, The "set nat-source-vip enable" should be applied in the VIP Otherwise, the IP address of the physical interface will be used for NAT
https://kb.fortinet.com/kb/documentLink.do?externalID=FD44529
C is correct, VIP doesnt affect source nat

comments.content:
I did not pay attention at the port forwarding feature
Port forwarding is enabled => correct answer is C
if port forwarding was disabled => A is the correct answer

discussion.content:
Answer A
FGT 6.4 Security Study guide P158

1- Traffic direction is important. 2- The second policy is related to port forwarding and not NAT. The question is related to source NAT = NAT(Traffic going from Lan(port2) to Wan(port1). In our case the router(fortigate) Wan interface IP will be use to Source Nat the workstation IP.

A is correct, The Exibit shows a VIP from 10.200.0.10 (you can have several IP addresses from your ISP) Static NAT with a port forward, then the 2nd policy Allow traffic from port1 (should say WAN instead of LAN, I think is a trick) to the VIP, so the IP that you need to use to access your web server is 10.200.0.10

C is the correct answer 
It cannot be the A because the exhibit shows the DNAT and not some one-to-one SNAT
A, Nat is enabled on the matching policy, so it won't be the original source interface address.

comments.content: Es A, tiene port forwarding habilitado.

choices.B: Any available IP address in the WAN (port1) subnet 10.200.1.0/24

questions.question_text: By default, when logging to disk, when does FortiGate delete logs?

discussion.content:
BCE correct answers
checked on FGT 
> SSL VPN Settings:
- Restrict Access -> Limit access to specific hosts
- Requie Client Certificate
> SSL VPN Portals 
- Host Check

D is not the rigth option.
what D does is " Hardware acceleration overview " 
Most FortiGate models have specialized acceleration hardware that can offload resource intensive processing from main processing (CPU) resources. Most FortiGate units include specialized content processors (CPs) that accelerate a wide range of important security processes such as virus scanning, attack detection, encryption and decryption. (Only selected entry-level FortiGate models do not include a CP processor.) Many FortiGate models also contain security processors (SPs) that accelerate processing for specific security features such as IPS and network processors (NPs) that offload processing of high volume network traffic.

questions.question_text: An administrator needs to strengthen the security for SSL VPN access. Which of the following statements are best practices to do so? (Choose three.)

choices.B: Configure host restrictions by IP or MAC address.
choices.C: Configure two-factor authentication using security certificates.
choices.A: Configure split tunneling for content inspection.
choices.D: Configure SSL offloading to a content processor (FortiASIC).
